And he is WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle master, Will Shortz.
I was on assignment in San Francisco recently, and it involved some food tasting.
So this is Chef Crenn's brioche served with a little bit of cultured butter and sea salt.
What's amazing about the brioche is it's actually the one unifying item across all three restaurants, so Petit Crenn, Bar Crenn and Atelier Crenn.
All of those restaurants are owned by Dominique Crenn, who wasn't surprised at all when I told her how good that bread was.
When it's, like, warm and buttery, it's delicious.
And it's so luscious and I will say luxurious that you feel so connected to the person that make the bread.
I was chatting with the French-born chef shortly after she got some news.
Her restaurant, Atelier Crenn, was given three stars by the Michelin Guide.
That is seen by some as the highest honor in the culinary world.
And what's more, of all the chefs in the U.S.
to get three stars from Michelin, Dominique Crenn is the first woman.
It's what we do with it that matters, you know?
- doesn't mean that we are better than others.
But she does think this gives her a better platform now to inspire women in an industry largely dominated by men.
Dominique Crenn says she has seen slow progress making kitchens more diverse and building respect for women there.
She's made her own way up in the San Francisco restaurant scene since moving here from France in her 20s.
When I start to work in a kitchen, there's not a lot of women that were working.
And I didn't try to pay attention to that.
But I knew there was something that - I had to work harder than others.
And I was a bit pick on sometime, but I'm a very strong person.
Picked on, like, the chef with...
Did you face people who thought you were moving quickly because you're a woman?
I'm not going to say his name.
(Laughter) He's, like, a fellow cook in the...
